head.title: When School and Home Are One

hedline.hl1: When School and Home Are One

abstract.p: Ricardo Munro letter, commenting on May 24 article on home schooling, offers praise for the home-schooled students he has taught in high schools; says good schools have nothing to fear from home schooling; cartoon

block.p: As a longtime public school classroom teacher, I must say that home schooling is not exclusive of public schooling (front page, May 24). I have seen some excellent results, especially when the adult in charge is a teacher or college graduate.

As a longtime public school classroom teacher, I must say that home schooling is not exclusive of public schooling (front page, May 24). I have seen some excellent results, especially when the adult in charge is a teacher or college graduate.

I have taught many ''home-schooled'' students for the simple reason that parents who teach their children are aware of their limitations and seek public school foreign language teachers and math teachers as tutors.

Many homeschoolers begin their public school education in the ninth grade. I welcome this small cohort of students who are, by and large, very polite and read above their grade level. I wish I could say that about even 30 percent of my high school students.
Nonetheless, if public schools are safe, clean and have high standards, then they have nothing to fear from competition from homeschoolers.
